Journal.Title: Environmental health : a global access science source

Article.ArticleTitle: The impact of long-term PM<sub>2.5</sub> exposure on specific causes of death: exposure-response curves and effect modification among 53 million U.S. Medicare beneficiaries.

AbstractText: The shape of the exposure-response curve for long-term ambient fine particulate (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) exposure and cause-specific mortality is poorly understood, especially for rural populations and underrepresented minorities.

We used hybrid machine learning and Cox proportional hazard models to assess the association of long-term PM<sub>2.5</sub> exposures on specific causes of death for 53 million U.S. Medicare beneficiaries (aged ≥65) from 2000 to 2008. Models included strata for age, sex, race, and ZIP code and controlled for neighborhood socio-economic status (SES) in our main analyses, with approximately 4 billion person-months of follow-up, and additionally for warm season average of 1-h daily maximum ozone exposures in a sensitivity analysis. The impact of non-traffic PM<sub>2.5</sub> on mortality was examined using two stage models of PM<sub>2.5</sub> and nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>).

A 10 μg /m<sup>3</sup> increase in 12-month average PM<sub>2.5</sub> prior to death was associated with a 5% increase in all-cause mortality, as well as an 8.8, 5.6, and 2.5% increase in all cardiovascular disease (CVD)-, all respiratory-, and all cancer deaths, respectively, in age, gender, race, ZIP code, and SES-adjusted models. PM<sub>2.5</sub> exposures, however, were not associated with lung cancer mortality. Results were not sensitive to control for ozone exposures. PM<sub>2.5</sub>-mortality associations for CVD- and respiratory-related causes were positive and significant for beneficiaries irrespective of their sex, race, age, SES and urbanicity, with no evidence of a lower threshold for response or of lower Risk Ratios (RRs) at low PM<sub>2.5</sub> levels. Associations between PM<sub>2.5</sub> and CVD and respiratory mortality were linear and were higher for younger, Black and urban beneficiaries, but were largely similar by SES. Risks associated with non-traffic PM<sub>2.5</sub> were lower than that for all PM<sub>2.5</sub> and were null for respiratory and lung cancer-related deaths.

PM<sub>2.5</sub> was associated with mortality from CVD, respiratory, and all cancer, but not lung cancer. PM<sub>2.5</sub>-associated risks of CVD and respiratory mortality were similar across PM<sub>2.5</sub> levels, with no evidence of a threshold. Blacks, urban, and younger beneficiaries were most vulnerable to the long-term impacts of PM<sub>2.5</sub> on mortality.
